keyFactors.title: Elite Recent Form
keyFactors.description: Cook was averaging 103.7 rushing yards over his last 3 games, well above the 84.5 line. One of NFL's most efficient backs entering Week 10.

keyFactors.title: Dolphins Run Defense Weakness
keyFactors.description: Miami ranked 24th against the run, allowing 128.6 rushing yards per game. Bills' ground game historically exploited their defensive vulnerabilities.

keyFactors.title: Workhorse Usage
keyFactors.description: Cook handled 78% of Bills' RB touches and averaged 18.2 carries per game. Clear bellcow role with no timeshare concerns.

riskFactors: Josh Allen's rushing ability could vulture goal-line carries
Potential shootout environment limiting run-game emphasis
Miami's offensive tempo could force Bills to pass more

quarterBreakdown.description: Cook managed just 8 yards on 3 carries as Bills fell behind early. Miami's defense stacked the box, forcing Buffalo to air it out.
Bills trailed 17-10 at half. Cook added 12 yards on 4 attempts but game script already working against ground game. Allen threw 21 first-half passes.
Playing catch-up entire second half. Cook totaled 11 yards on 4 second-half carries as Bills abandoned run game. Allen threw 24 second-half passes in comeback effort.

gameResults.whenMissed: Never approached line - stuck at 31 yards, needed 84.5
gameResults.gamePace: High-scoring shootout (30-27) forced Bills into pass-heavy attack. Allen threw 45 passes vs just 11 Cook carries. Game script disaster from opening kickoff.

whatWentWrong.title: Catastrophic Game Script
whatWentWrong.description: Bills trailed most of game and never established run. Cook's 11 carries was season-low. Allen threw 45 passes in shootout environment - complete abandonment of ground game.

whatWentWrong.title: Miami Stacked the Box
whatWentWrong.description: Dolphins loaded box on early downs, daring Bills to throw. Cook averaged just 2.8 YPC (vs 5.1 season average), facing 8+ defenders on 73% of rush attempts.

whatWentWrong.title: Volume Evaporated
whatWentWrong.description: Cook needed 18+ carries to hit 84.5 yards at typical efficiency. Got just 11 attempts - 39% below season average. No volume = no chance.

statisticalContext.percentileRanking: Bottom 5% of Cook's season performances - worst game of year

postGameAnalysis.wasNormalVariance: This was 70% game script variance, 30% analytical error. The projection assumed competitive game flow allowing Bills to establish run. However, trailing from start and Miami's box-stacking forced complete pass-game reliance. Cook's 11 carries (vs 18.2 season avg) shows volume never materialized. Difficult to predict Bills falling behind and abandoning run entirely.

closingLineValue.verdict: Positive CLV - line moved toward over as market recognized Cook's elite form and favorable matchup.

keyTakeaways: RB rushing props require competitive game script - when team trails and passes 45 times, even elite backs can't produce
Cook's 11 carries (season-low) vs 18.2 average shows importance of volume projections
Miami stacking box (8+ defenders on 73% of plays) destroyed efficiency - couldn't get 2.8 YPC up to needed 7.7 YPC
Shootout environments (30-27 final) kill rushing volume for trailing teams
Even with positive CLV and strong recent form, game flow trumps everything for RB yardage props
verdict: Strong pre-game analysis but game script disaster. Bills' deficit from opening drive forced pass-heavy attack. Cook's season-low 11 carries made 84.5 yards mathematically impossible. Shootout environment was predictable risk that materialized - should have weighted potential negative game script more heavily given Miami's offensive firepower.
